0.text: Twelfth Night; or, What You Will

12.text: [Enter VIOLA, and CLOWN with a tabor.]

15.text:
VIOLA.
Save thee, friend, and thy music! dost thou

20.text:
CLOWN.
No, sir, I live by the church.

24.text:
CLOWN.
No such matter, sir: I do live by the church;

27.text:
for I do live at my
house, and my house doth stand by the church.

31.text:
VIOLA.
So thou mayst say, the king lies by a beggar,

35.text:
if a beggar dwell
near him; or the church stands by thy tabor,

38.text:
if thy tabor stand
by the church.

40.text:
CLOWN.
You have said, sir. To see this age! A sentence

44.text:
is but a cheveril
glove to a good wit; how quickly the wrong

49.text:
VIOLA.
Nay, that's certain; they that dally nicely

52.text:
with words may
quickly make them wanton.

54.text:
CLOWN.
I would, therefore, my sister had had no name,

60.text:
CLOWN.
Why, sir, her name's a word; and to dally

63.text:
with that word might
make my sister wanton. But, indeed, words

67.text:
are very rascals since
bonds disgrac'd them.

72.text:
CLOWN.
Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words;

75.text:
and words are
grown so false, I am loth to prove reason

80.text:
VIOLA.
I warrant thou art a merry fellow, and car'st

84.text:
CLOWN.
Not so, sir; I do care for something; but

86.text:
in my conscience, sir,
I do not care for you: if that be to care

91.text:
for nothing, sir, I
would it would make you invisible.

94.text:
VIOLA.
Art not thou the Lady Olivia's fool?

97.text:
CLOWN.
No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly:

101.text:
she will keep no
fool, sir, till she be married; and fools

105.text:
are as like husbands as
pilchards are to herrings, the husband's the

109.text:
bigger. I am,
indeed, not her fool, but her corrupter of

115.text:
VIOLA.
I saw thee late at the Count Orsino's.

117.text:
CLOWN.
Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like

121.text:
the sun, it shines
everywhere. I would be sorry, sir, but the

125.text:
fool should be as oft
with your master as with my mistress. I think

131.text:
VIOLA.
Nay, and thou pass upon me, I'll no more with

135.text:
thee. Hold,
there's expenses for thee.

137.text:
CLOWN.
Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send

142.text:
VIOLA.
By my troth, I'll tell thee, I am almost sick

144.text:
for one; [Aside]
though I would not have it grow on my chin.

150.text:
CLOWN.
Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?

154.text:
VIOLA.
Yes, being kept together and put to use.

157.text:
CLOWN.
I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir,

160.text:
to bring a Cressida
to this Troilus.

162.text:
VIOLA.
I understand you, sir; 't is well begg'd.

165.text:
CLOWN.
The matter, I hope, is not great, sir, begging

169.text:
but a beggar.
Cressida was a beggar. My lady is within,

173.text:
sir. I will construe to
them whence you come; who you are and what

178.text:
you would are out of
my welkin,— I might say 'element,' but the

183.text:
VIOLA.
This fellow is wise enough to play the fool;

188.text:
And to do that well craves a kind of wit:
He must observe their mood on whom he jests,

193.text:
The quality of persons, and the time;
And, like the haggard, check at every feather

197.text:
That comes before his eye. This is a practice
As full of labour as a wise man's art:

202.text:
For folly that he wisely shows is fit;
But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their

216.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Dieu vous garde, monsieur.

218.text:
VIOLA.
Et vous aussi; votre serviteur.

220.text:
SIR ANDREW.
I hope, sir, you are; and I am yours.

225.text:
SIR TOBY.
Will you encounter the house? my niece is

228.text:
desirous you should
enter, if your trade be to her.

232.text:
VIOLA.
I am bound to your niece, sir; I mean, she

235.text:
is the list of my
voyage.

236.text:
SIR TOBY.
Taste your legs, sir; put them to motion.

239.text:
VIOLA.
My legs do better understand me, sir, than

242.text:
I understand what you
mean by bidding me taste my legs.

244.text:
SIR TOBY.
I mean, to go, sir, to enter.

247.text:
VIOLA.
I will answer you with gait and entrance.

255.text:
Most excellent accomplish'd lady, the heavens
rain odours on you!

258.text:
SIR ANDREW.
That youth's a rare courtier. 'Rain odours';

264.text:
VIOLA.
My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your

267.text:
own most pregnant and
vouchsafed ear.

276.text:
OLIVIA.
Let the garden door be shut, and leave me

279.text:
to my hearing.
[Exeunt SIR TOBY, SIR ANDREW, and MARIA.]

287.text:
VIOLA.
My duty, madam, and most humble service.

292.text:
VIOLA.
Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.

295.text:
OLIVIA.
My servant, sir! 'T was never merry world

298.text:
Since lowly feigning was call'd compliment;
You're servant to the Count Orsino, youth.

305.text:
VIOLA.
And he is yours, and his must needs be yours;

308.text: Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.

311.text:
OLIVIA.
For him, I think not on him; for his thoughts,

315.text:
Would they were blanks, rather than fill'd
with me!

317.text:
VIOLA.
Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts

321.text:
OLIVIA.
O, by your leave, I pray you,

323.text:
I bade you never speak again of him;
But, would you undertake another suit,

328.text:
I had rather hear you to solicit that
Than music from the spheres.

333.text:
OLIVIA.
Give me leave, beseech you. I did send,

337.text:
After the last enchantment you did here,
A ring in chase of you; so did I abuse

342.text:
Myself, my servant, and, I fear me, you.
Under your hard construction must I sit,

350.text:
To force that on you, in a shameful cunning,
Which you knew none of yours; what might you

355.text:
think?
Have you not set mine honour at the stake,

359.text:
And baited it with all th' unmuzzled thoughts
That tyrannous heart can think? To one of

364.text:
your receiving
Enough is shown. A cypress, not a bosom,

369.text: Hides my heart. So, let me hear you speak.

374.text:
OLIVIA.
That's a degree to love.

375.text:
VIOLA.
No, not a grize; for 't is a vulgar proof,

380.text: That very oft we pity enemies.

381.text:
OLIVIA.
Why, then methinks 't is time to smile again.

385.text:
O world, how apt the poor are to be proud!
If one should be a prey, how much the better

391.text:
To fall before the lion than the wolf! [Clock
strikes]

396.text:
The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.
Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have

403.text:
you;
And yet, when wit and youth is come to harvest,

409.text:
Your wife is like to reap a proper man.
There lies your way, due west.

416.text:
VIOLA.
Then westward-ho! Grace and good disposition

419.text:
Attend your ladyship!
You'll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?

424.text: I prithee, tell me what thou think'st of me.

427.text:
VIOLA.
That you do think you are not what you are.

430.text:
OLIVIA.
If I think so, I think the same of you.

433.text:
VIOLA.
Then think you right; I am not what I am.

436.text:
OLIVIA.
I would you were as I would have you be!

438.text:
VIOLA.
Would it be better, madam, than I am?

441.text: I wish it might, for now I am your fool.

444.text:
OLIVIA.
O, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful

447.text:
In the contempt and anger of his lip!
A murd'rous guilt shows not itself more soon

453.text:
Than love that would seem hid; love's night
is noon.

458.text:
Cesario, by the roses of the spring,
By maidhood, honour, truth, and every thing,

466.text:
I love thee so, that, maugre all thy pride,
Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.

474.text:
Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,
For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause;

481.text:
But rather reason thus with reason fetter,
Love sought is good, but given unsought is

489.text:
VIOLA.
By innocence I swear, and by my youth,

492.text:
I have one heart, one bosom, and one truth,
And that no woman has; nor never none

498.text:
Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.
And so adieu, good madam; never more

503.text: Will I my master's tears to you deplore.

505.text:
OLIVIA.
Yet come again; for thou perhaps mayst move

509.text:
That heart, which now abhors, to like his
love.

522.text: [Enter SIR TOBY, SIR ANDREW and FABIAN.]

526.text:
SIR ANDREW.
No, faith, I'll not stay a jot longer.

529.text:
SIR TOBY.
Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.

534.text:
FABIAN.
You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.

538.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Marry, I saw your niece do more favours to

541.text:
the count's
serving-man than ever she bestow'd upon me;

546.text:
SIR TOBY.
Did she see thee the while, old boy? tell

550.text:
SIR ANDREW.
As plain as I see you now.

552.text:
FABIAN.
This was a great argument of love in her toward

557.text:
SIR ANDREW.
'Slight, will you make an ass o' me?

559.text:
FABIAN.
I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the

564.text:
SIR TOBY.
And they have been grand-jurymen since before

569.text:
FABIAN.
She did show favour to the youth in your sight

572.text:
only to exasperate
you, to awake your dormouse valour, to put

576.text:
fire in your heart,
and brimstone in your liver. You should then

581.text:
have accosted her;
and with some excellent jests, fire-new from

585.text:
the mint, you should
have bang'd the youth into dumbness. This

589.text:
was look'd for at your
hand, and this was balk'd: the double gilt

593.text:
of this opportunity
you let time wash off, and you are now sail'd

597.text:
into the north of
my lady's opinion; where you will hang like

600.text:
an icicle on
Dutchman's beard, unless you do redeem it

603.text:
by some laudable
attempt either of valour or policy.

606.text:
SIR ANDREW.
And't be any way, it must be with valour;

610.text:
for policy I hate: I
had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.

615.text:
SIR TOBY.
Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the

619.text:
basis of valour.
Challenge me the count's youth to fight with

623.text:
him; hurt him in
eleven places: my niece shall take note of

628.text:
it; and assure
thyself, there is no love-broker in the world

633.text:
can more prevail in
man's commendation with woman than report

639.text:
FABIAN.
There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.

642.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Will either of you bear me a challenge to

647.text:
SIR TOBY.
Go, write it in a martial hand; be curst and

652.text:
brief; it is no
matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full

657.text:
of invention; taunt
him with the license of ink; if thou thou'st

664.text:
him some
thrice, it shall not be amiss; and as many

668.text:
lies as will lie in
thy sheet of paper, although the sheet were

673.text:
big enough for the
bed of Ware in England, set 'em down: go,

680.text:
about it. Let there be
gall enough in thy ink; though thou write

685.text:
with a goose-pen, no
matter: about it.

689.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Where shall I find you?

690.text:
SIR TOBY.
We'll call thee at the cubiculo. Go.

695.text:
FABIAN.
This is a dear manakin to you, Sir Toby.

697.text:
SIR TOBY.
I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand

702.text:
FABIAN.
We shall have a rare letter from him; but

706.text:
SIR TOBY.
Never trust me, then; and by all means stir

710.text:
on the youth to an
answer. I think oxen and wain-ropes cannot

715.text:
hale them together.
For Andrew, if he were open'd, and you find

720.text:
so much blood in his
liver as will clog the foot of a flea, I'll

725.text:
eat the rest of th'
anatomy.

727.text:
FABIAN.
And his opposite, the youth, bears in his

730.text:
visage no great presage
of cruelty.

732.text:
SIR TOBY.
Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.

737.text:
MARIA.
If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourselves

741.text:
into
stitches, follow me. Yond gull Malvolio is

745.text:
turn'd heathen, a very
renegado; for there is no Christian, that

749.text:
means to be sav'd by
believing rightly, can ever believe such impossible

754.text:
passages of
grossness. He's in yellow stockings.

758.text:
MARIA.
Most villainously; like a pedant that keeps

761.text:
a school i' th'
church. I have dogg'd him, like his murderer.

764.text:
He does obey every
point of the letter that I dropp'd to betray

768.text:
him; he does smile
his face into more lines than is in the new

772.text:
map, with the
augmentation of the Indies: you have not seen

775.text:
such a thing as 't
is. I can hardly forbear hurling things at

779.text:
him. I know my lady
will strike him; if she do, he'll smile, and

784.text:
SIR TOBY.
Come, bring us, bring us where he is.

803.text:
SEBASTIAN.
I would not by my will have troubled you;

806.text:
But, since you make your pleasure of your
pains,

808.text: I will no further chide you.

810.text:
ANTONIO.
I could not stay behind you: my desire,

813.text:
More sharp than filed steel, did spur me forth;
And not all love to see you, though so much

820.text:
As might have drawn one to a longer voyage,
But jealousy what might befall your travel,

827.text:
Being skilless in these parts; which to a
stranger,

830.text:
Unguided and unfriended, often prove
Rough and unhospitable. My willing love,

837.text:
The rather by these arguments of fear,
Set forth in your pursuit.

843.text:
I can no other answer make but thanks,
And thanks, and ever thanks; too oft good

849.text:
turns
Are shuffl'd off with such uncurrent pay:

852.text:
But, were my worth as is my conscience firm,
You should find better dealing. What's to

857.text:
do?
Shall we go see the reliques of this town?

860.text:
ANTONIO.
To-morrow, sir; best first go see your lodging.

864.text:
SEBASTIAN.
I am not weary, and 't is long to night;

868.text:
I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes
With the memorials and the things of fame

875.text:
I do not without danger walk these streets.
Once, in a sea-fight, 'gainst the count his

881.text:
galleys
I did some service; of such note indeed,

885.text:
That, were I ta'en here, it would scarce be
answer'd.

890.text:
SEBASTIAN.
Belike you slew great number of his people.

893.text:
ANTONIO.
Th' offence is not of such a bloody nature;

897.text:
Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel
Might well have given us bloody argument.

903.text:
It might have since been answer'd in repaying
What we took from them; which, for traffic's

909.text:
sake,
Most of our city did: only myself stood out;

914.text:
For which, if I be lapsed in this place,
I shall pay dear.

919.text:
SEBASTIAN.
Do not then walk too open.

922.text:
ANTONIO.
It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, here's my purse.

926.text:
In the south suburbs, at the Elephant,
Is best to lodge. I will bespeak our diet,

933.text:
Whiles you beguile the time and feed your
knowledge

936.text:
With viewing of the town; there shall you
have me.

942.text:
ANTONIO.
Haply your eye shall light upon some toy

945.text:
You have desire to purchase; and your store,
I think, is not for idle markets, sir.

952.text:
SEBASTIAN.
I'll be your purse-bearer, and leave you

973.text:
OLIVIA.
I have sent after him; he says he'll come.

977.text:
How shall I feast him? what bestow of him?
For youth is bought more oft than begg'd or

985.text:
Where's Malvolio? He is sad and civil,
And suits well for a servant with my fortunes.

995.text:
MARIA.
He's coming, madam, but in very strange manner.

1000.text:
OLIVIA.
Why, what's the matter? does he rave?

1003.text:
MARIA.
No, madam, he does nothing but smile. Your

1007.text:
ladyship were best to
have some guard about you, if he come; for,

1010.text:
sure, the man is
tainted in's wits.

1015.text:
I am as mad as he,
If sad and merry madness equal be.

1030.text: I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.

1032.text:
MALVOLIO.
Sad, lady! I could be sad; this does make

1038.text:
some obstruction in the
blood, this cross-gartering; but what of that?

1047.text:
if it please the
eye of one, it is with me as the very true

1052.text: sonnet is, 'Please one, and please all.'

1056.text:
OLIVIA.
Why, how dost thou, man? what is the matter

1061.text:
MALVOLIO.
Not black in my mind, though yellow in my

1064.text:
legs. It did come to
his hands, and commands shall be executed;

1073.text:
I think we do know the
sweet Roman hand.

1077.text:
OLIVIA.
Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?

1080.text:
MALVOLIO.
To bed! ay, sweet-heart, and I'll come to

1087.text:
OLIVIA.
God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so and

1093.text:
MALVOLIO.
At your request! yes; nightingales answer

1101.text:
MARIA.
Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness

1105.text:
MALVOLIO.
'Be not afraid of greatness'; 'twas well writ.

1110.text:
OLIVIA.
What mean'st thou by that, Malvolio?

1121.text:
MALVOLIO.
'And some have greatness thrust upon them.'

1128.text:
MALVOLIO.
'Remember who commended thy yellow stockings,'—

1134.text:
MALVOLIO.
'And wish'd to see thee cross-garter'd.'

1140.text:
MALVOLIO.
'Go to, thou art made, if thou desir'st to

1148.text:
MALVOLIO.
'If not, let me see thee a servant still.'

1153.text:
OLIVIA.
Why, this is very midsummer madness.

1159.text:
SERVANT.
Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino's

1162.text:
is return'd: I
could hardly entreat him back: he attends

1166.text:
OLIVIA.
I'll come to him. [Exit SERVANT] Good Maria,

1171.text:
let this fellow be
look'd to. Where's my cousin Toby? Let some

1175.text:
of my people have a
special care of him; I would not have him

1178.text:
miscarry for the half
of my dowry.

1183.text:
MALVOLIO.
O, ho! do you come near me now? no worse man

1191.text:
than Sir Toby to
look to me! This concurs directly with the

1196.text:
letter: she sends him
on purpose, that I may appear stubborn to

1202.text:
him; for she incites me
to that in the letter. 'Cast thy humble slough,'

1208.text:
says she; 'be
opposite with kinsman, surly with servants;

1212.text:
let thy tongue tang
with arguments of state; put thyself into

1216.text:
the trick of
singularity'; and, consequently, sets down

1221.text:
the manner how; as, a
sad face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue,

1226.text:
in the habit of
some sir of note, and so forth. I have lim'd

1231.text:
her; but it is
Jove's doing, and Jove make me thankful! And

1236.text:
when she went away
now, 'Let this fellow be look'd to'; fellow!

1243.text:
not Malvolio, nor
after my degree, but fellow. Why, every thing

1250.text:
adheres together,
that no dram of a scruple, no scruple of a

1255.text:
scruple, no obstacle,
no incredulous or unsafe circumstance,—

1260.text:
what can be said?
Nothing that can be can come between me and

1265.text:
the full prospect of
my hopes. Well, Jove, not I, is the doer of

1272.text:
this, and he is to be
thank'd.

1276.text: [Re-enter MARIA, with SIR TOBY and FABIAN.]

1278.text:
SIR TOBY.
Which way is he, in the name of sanctity?

1282.text:
If all the devils of
hell be drawn in little, and Legion himself

1286.text:
possessed him, yet I
'll speak to him.

1290.text:
FABIAN.
Here he is, here he is. How is 't with you,

1294.text:
sir? how is 't with
you, man?

1297.text:
MALVOLIO.
Go off; I discard you: let me enjoy my private;

1304.text:
MARIA.
Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks within him!

1307.text:
did not I tell you?
Sir Toby, my lady prays you to have a care

1311.text:
MALVOLIO.
Ah, ha! does she so?

1313.text:
SIR TOBY.
Go to, go to; peace, peace; we must deal gently

1318.text:
with him: let me
alone. How do you, Malvolio? how is 't with

1327.text:
you? What, man! defy
the devil; consider, he 's an enemy to mankind.

1333.text:
MALVOLIO.
Do you know what you say?

1337.text:
MARIA.
La you, and you speak ill of the devil, how

1340.text:
he takes it at heart!
Pray God, he be not bewitch'd! My lady would

1343.text:
not lose him for
more than I 'll say.

1348.text:
SIR TOBY.
Prithee, hold thy peace; this is not the way:

1353.text:
do you not see you
move him? let me alone with him.

1358.text:
FABIAN.
No way but gentleness; gently, gently: the

1363.text:
fiend is rough, and
will not be roughly us'd.

1365.text:
SIR TOBY.
Why, how now, my bawcock! how dost thou, chuck?

1371.text:
SIR TOBY.
Ay, Biddy, come with me. What, man! 't is

1376.text:
not for gravity to play
at cherry-pit with Satan. Hang him, foul collier!

1381.text:
MARIA.
Get him to say his prayers; good Sir Toby,

1387.text:
MARIA.
No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.

1390.text:
MALVOLIO.
Go, hang yourselves all! you are idle shallow

1394.text:
things. I am not of
your element; you shall know more hereafter.

1404.text:
FABIAN.
If this were play'd upon a stage now, I could

1409.text:
condemn it as an
improbable fiction.

1410.text:
SIR TOBY.
His very genius hath taken the infection of

1415.text:
MARIA.
Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take

1419.text:
FABIAN.
Why, we shall make him mad indeed.

1422.text:
MARIA.
The house will be the quieter.

1424.text:
SIR TOBY.
Come, we 'll have him in a dark room and bound.

1429.text:
My niece is
already in the belief that he 's mad: we may

1435.text:
carry it thus, for
our pleasure and his penance, till our very

1441.text:
pastime, tired out of
breath, prompt us to have mercy on him; at

1447.text:
which time we will
bring the device to the bar, and crown thee

1453.text:
for a finder of
madmen. But see, but see.

1459.text:
FABIAN.
More matter for a May morning.

1461.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Here 's the challenge, read it; I warrant

1469.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Ay, is 't, I warrant him; do but read.

1473.text:
SIR TOBY.
Give me. [Reads] Youth, whatsoever thou art,

1479.text:
thou art but a
scurvy fellow.

1486.text:
SIR TOBY.
[Reads] Wonder not, nor admire not in thy

1491.text:
mind, why I do call
thee so, for I will show thee no reason for

1499.text:
FABIAN.
A good note; that keeps you from the blow

1502.text:
SIR TOBY.
[Reads] Thou com'st to the lady Olivia, and

1508.text:
in my sight she uses
thee kindly: but thou liest in thy throat;

1515.text:
that is not the matter
I challenge thee for.

1519.text:
FABIAN.
Very brief, and to exceeding good sense—

1524.text:
SIR TOBY.
[Reads] I will waylay thee going home; where

1529.text:
if it be thy chance
to kill me,—

1534.text:
SIR TOBY.
[Reads.] Thou kill 'st me like a rogue and

1538.text:
FABIAN.
Still you keep o' th' windy side of the law;

1544.text:
SIR TOBY.
[Reads] Fare thee well; and God have mercy

1547.text:
upon one of our souls!
He may have mercy upon mine; but my hope is

1553.text:
better, and so look
to thyself. Thy friend, as thou usest him,

1562.text:
and thy sworn enemy,
ANDREW AGUECHEEK.

1567.text:
If this letter move him not, his legs cannot;
I'll give 't him.

1571.text:
MARIA.
You may have very fit occasion for 't; he

1574.text:
is now in some commerce
with my lady, and will by and by depart.

1577.text:
SIR TOBY.
Go, Sir Andrew; scout me for him at the corner

1581.text:
of the orchard,
like a bum-baily. So soon as ever thou see'st

1586.text:
him, draw; and as
thou drawest, swear horrible; for it comes

1591.text:
to pass oft, that a
terrible oath, with a swaggering accent sharply

1595.text:
twang'd off,
gives manhood more approbation than ever proof

1600.text:
itself would have
earn'd him. Away!

1603.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Nay, let me alone for swearing.

1608.text:
SIR TOBY.
Now will not I deliver his letter; for the

1611.text:
behaviour of the young
gentleman gives him out to be of good capacity

1615.text:
and breeding; his
employment between his lord and my niece confirms

1620.text:
no less:
therefore this letter, being so excellently

1625.text:
ignorant, will breed
no terror in the youth; he will find it comes

1630.text:
from a clodpole.
But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by

1635.text:
word of mouth; set upon
Aguecheek a notable report of valour; and

1641.text:
drive the gentleman, as
I know his youth will aptly receive it, into

1646.text:
a most hideous
opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity.

1653.text:
This will so
fright them both, that they will kill one

1656.text:
another by the look,
like cockatrices.

1662.text:
FABIAN.
Here he comes with your niece; give them way

1665.text:
till he take leave,
and presently after him.

1668.text:
SIR TOBY.
I will meditate the while upon some horrid

1677.text:
OLIVIA.
I have said too much unto a heart of stone,

1681.text:
And laid mine honour too unchary out.
There 's something in me that reproves my

1686.text:
fault;
But such a headstrong potent fault it is,

1692.text:
VIOLA.
With the same haviour that your passion bears,

1696.text:
OLIVIA.
Here, wear this jewel for me, 't is my picture:

1701.text:
Refuse it not; it hath no tongue to vex you:
And I beseech you come again to-morrow.

1709.text:
What shall you ask of me that I 'll deny,
That honour sav'd may upon asking give?

1714.text:
VIOLA.
Nothing but this,— your true love for my

1718.text:
OLIVIA.
How with mine honour may I give him that

1720.text: Which I have given to you?

1723.text:
OLIVIA.
Well, come again to-morrow; fare thee well.

1727.text:
A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.
[Exit.]

1736.text:
SIR TOBY.
Gentleman, God save thee!

1740.text:
SIR TOBY.
That defence thou hast, betake thee to 't.

1745.text:
Of what nature the
wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not;

1749.text:
but thy intercepter,
full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends

1755.text:
thee at the
orchard-end. Dismount thy tuck, be yare in

1760.text:
thy preparation; for
thy assailant is quick, skilful, and deadly.

1764.text:
VIOLA.
You mistake, sir; I am sure no man hath any

1767.text:
quarrel to me: my
remembrance is very free and clear from any

1771.text:
image of offence done
to any man.

1773.text:
SIR TOBY.
You'll find it otherwise, I assure you. Therefore,

1777.text:
if you hold
your life at any price, betake you to your

1782.text:
guard; for your
opposite hath in him what youth, strength,

1786.text:
skill, and wrath can
furnish man withal.

1789.text:
VIOLA.
I pray you, sir, what is he?

1791.text:
SIR TOBY.
He is knight, dubb'd with unhatch'd rapier

1795.text:
and on carpet
consideration; but he is a devil in private

1801.text:
brawl: souls and
bodies hath he divorc'd three; and his incensement

1807.text:
at this moment
is so implacable that satisfaction can be

1812.text:
none but by pangs of
death and sepulchre. Hob, nob, is his word;

1819.text:
VIOLA.
I will return again into the house and desire

1821.text:
some conduct of the
lady. I am no fighter. I have heard of some

1826.text:
kind of men that put
quarrels purposely on others, to taste their

1829.text:
valour; belike this
is a man of that quirk.

1831.text:
SIR TOBY.
Sir, no; his indignation derives itself out

1835.text:
of a very competent
injury. Therefore get you on and give him

1840.text:
his desire. Back you
shall not to the house, unless you undertake

1845.text:
that with
me which with as much safety you might answer

1849.text:
him. Therefore on,
or strip your sword stark naked; for meddle

1855.text:
you must, that 's
certain, or forswear to wear iron about you.

1861.text:
VIOLA.
This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech you,

1864.text:
do me this
courteous office, as to know of the knight

1866.text:
what my offence to him
is; it is something of my negligence, nothing

1871.text:
SIR TOBY.
I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by

1876.text:
VIOLA.
Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?

1880.text:
FABIAN.
I know the knight is incens'd against you,

1882.text:
even to a mortal
arbitrement; but nothing of the circumstance

1887.text:
VIOLA.
I beseech you, what manner of man is he?

1889.text:
FABIAN.
Nothing of that wonderful promise, to read

1892.text:
him by his form, as
you are like to find him in the proof of his

1895.text:
valour. He is,
indeed, sir, the most skilful, bloody, and

1899.text:
fatal opposite that
you could possibly have found in any part

1902.text:
of Illyria. Will you
walk towards him? I will make your peace with

1906.text:
VIOLA.
I shall be much bound to you for 't. I am

1909.text:
one that had rather go
with sir priest than sir knight; I care not

1912.text:
who knows so much of
my mettle.

1919.text:
SIR TOBY.
Why, man, he's a very devil; I have not seen

1923.text:
such a firago. I had
a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all,

1928.text:
and he gives me the
stuck in with such a mortal motion that it

1932.text:
is
inevitable; and, on the answer, he pays you

1936.text:
as surely as your
feet hit the ground they step on. They say

1941.text:
he has been fencer to
the Sophy.

1943.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Pox on 't, I'll not meddle with him.

1946.text:
SIR TOBY.
Ay, but he will not now be pacified; Fabian

1953.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Plague on 't; and I thought he had been valiant

1957.text:
and so cunning in
fence, I'd have seen him damn'd ere I 'd have

1962.text:
challeng'd him. Let
him let the matter slip, and I 'll give him

1967.text:
SIR TOBY.
I 'll make the motion. Stand here, make a

1971.text:
good show on 't; this
shall end without the perdition of souls.

1977.text:
[Aside] Marry, I 'll
ride your horse as well as I ride you.

1985.text:
[To FABIAN] I have his horse to take up the
quarrel; I have

1990.text: persuaded him the youth 's a devil.

1993.text:
FABIAN.
He is as horribly conceited of him; and pants

1997.text:
and looks pale, as
if a bear were at his heels.

2000.text:
SIR TOBY.
[To VIOLA] There 's no remedy, sir: he will

2004.text:
fight with you for 's
oath sake. Marry, he hath better bethought

2009.text:
him of his quarrel,
and he finds that now scarce to be worth talking

2014.text:
of: therefore
draw, for the supportance of his vow; he protests

2022.text:
VIOLA.
[Aside] Pray God defend me! A little thing

2026.text:
would make me tell
them how much I lack of a man.

2028.text:
FABIAN.
Give ground, if you see him furious.

2030.text:
SIR TOBY.
Come, Sir Andrew, there's no remedy; the gentleman

2035.text:
will, for his
honour's sake, have one bout with you; he

2039.text:
cannot by the duello
avoid it; but he has promis'd me, as he is

2044.text:
a gentleman and a
soldier, he will not hurt you. Come on; to

2050.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Pray God, he keep his oath!

2052.text:
VIOLA.
I do assure you 't is against my will. [They

2058.text:
ANTONIO.
Put up your sword. If this young gentleman

2062.text:
Have done offence, I take the fault on me;
If you offend him, I for him defy you.

2070.text:
SIR TOBY.
You, sir! why, what are you?

2072.text:
ANTONIO.
One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more

2077.text: Than you have heard him brag to you he will.

2081.text:
SIR TOBY.
Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.

2087.text:
FABIAN.
O good Sir Toby, hold! here come the officers.

2091.text:
SIR TOBY.
I 'll be with you anon.

2093.text:
VIOLA.
Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.

2096.text:
SIR ANDREW.
Marry, will I, sir; and, for that I promis'd

2099.text:
you, I 'll be as
good as my word; he will bear you easily,

2105.text:
1 OFFICER.
This is the man; do thy office.

2108.text:
2 OFFICER.
Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit

2112.text:
ANTONIO.
You do mistake me, sir.

2114.text:
1 OFFICER.
No, sir, no jot; I know your favour well,

2118.text:
Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.
Take him away; he knows I know him well.

2123.text:
ANTONIO.
I must obey. [To VIOLA] This comes with seeking

2128.text:
you:
But there's no remedy; I shall answer it.

2132.text:
What will you do, now my necessity
Makes me to ask you for my purse? It grieves

2139.text:
me
Much more for what I cannot do for you

2142.text:
Than what befalls myself. You stand amaz'd;
But be of comfort.

2151.text:
ANTONIO.
I must entreat of you some of that money.

2156.text:
For the fair kindness you have show'd me here,
And, part, being prompted by your present

2161.text:
trouble,
Out of my lean and low ability

2162.text:
I 'll lend you something. My having is not
much;

2165.text:
I 'll make division of my present with you:
Hold, there 's half my coffer.

2169.text:
ANTONIO.
Will you deny me now?

2171.text:
Is 't possible that my deserts to you
Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery,

2180.text:
Lest that it make me so unsound a man
As to upbraid you with those kindnesses

2186.text: That I have done for you.

2190.text:
Nor know I you by voice or any feature.
I hate ingratitude more in a man

2195.text:
Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,
Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption

2202.text:
2 OFFICER.
Come, sir, I pray you, go.

2205.text:
ANTONIO.
Let me speak a little. This youth that you

2209.text:
see here
I snatch'd one half out of the jaws of death,

2215.text:
Reliev'd him with such sanctity of love,
And to his image, which methought did promise

2221.text: Most venerable worth, did I devotion.

2224.text:
1 OFFICER.
What 's that to us? The time goes by; away!

2228.text:
ANTONIO.
But O how vile an idol proves this god!

2233.text:
Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.
In nature there 's no blemish but the mind;

2241.text:
None can be call'd deform'd but the unkind.
Virtue is beauty; but the beauteous evil

2248.text: Are empty trunks, o'erflourish'd by the devil.

2252.text:
1 OFFICER.
The man grows mad; away with him!

2260.text:
VIOLA.
Methinks his words do from such passion fly

2263.text:
That he believes himself; so do not I.
Prove true, imagination, O, prove true,

2270.text: That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!

2273.text:
SIR TOBY.
Come hither, knight; come hither, Fabian;

2275.text:
we 'll whisper o'er a
couplet or two of most sage saws.

2280.text:
VIOLA.
He nam'd Sebastian. I my brother know

2283.text:
Yet living in my glass; even such and so
In favour was my brother; and he went

2288.text:
Still in this fashion, colour, ornament,
For him I imitate. O, if it prove,

2294.text:
Tempests are kind, and salt waves fresh in
love!

2298.text:
SIR TOBY.
A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward

2302.text:
than a hare: his
dishonesty appears in leaving his friend here

2307.text:
in necessity and
denying him; and for his cowardship, ask Fabian.

2313.text:
FABIAN.
A coward, a most devout coward, religious

2318.text:
SIR ANDREW.
'Slid, I'll after him again and beat him.

2321.text:
SIR TOBY.
Do; cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.

2326.text:
SIR ANDREW.
And I do not,—

2330.text:
FABIAN.
Come, let's see the event.

2332.text:
SIR TOBY.
I dare lay any money 't will be nothing yet.

2340.text:
End of Scene IV.
End of Act III.
